name: Odesa
fun_fact: Fun fact: Odesa's Privoz Market, operating since 1827, is called 'the stomach of Odessa' and birthplace of legendary Odesa humor. Market sellers are famous for interspersing sales with jokes and aphorismsâ€”a 200-year-old culture of wit that defines the city's character.

hero_dishes.name: Forshmak
hero_dishes.description: The crown dish of Odesaâ€”a delicate herring and apple pÃ¢tÃ© with butter, lemon juice, onions, and often eggs or walnuts, served cold with black bread
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brought to Odesa by Ashkenazi Jews from Poland/Lithuania, 'vorschmack' means 'pre-taste' or 'appetizer' in Yiddish. It instantly became Odesa's signature dish, associated with grandmas who prepared it for every holiday.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served in glass terrine jars at restaurants throughout Odesa, often with triangular black bread croutons

hero_dishes.name: Pilaf with Mussels
hero_dishes.description: Black Sea seafood specialtyâ€”mussels often fried on-site on large iron sheets, then mixed with pilaf rice
hero_dishes.origin_story: Odesa's port status makes fresh Black Sea seafood central to local cuisine. This dish combines Ukrainian pilaf traditions with Mediterranean seafood culture.

hero_dishes.name: Rachky/Rachki (Boiled Shrimp)
hero_dishes.description: Small pink Black Sea shrimp, a traditional Odesa snack eaten whole with or without a skewer, also used to stuff fish fillets
hero_dishes.origin_story: Using Odesite slang 'rachky,' these tiny shrimp are a beloved local street food, reflecting the port city's seafood-centric culture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Privoz Market, Lanzheron Beach, and Columbus Fish Club on the seashore

hero_dishes.name: Schalet Soup
hero_dishes.description: Stuffed chicken broth soup with dumplings, nicknamed 'Odessa penicillin' by locals for its healing properties
hero_dishes.origin_story: Part of Odesa's Ashkenazi Jewish culinary heritage, this comforting soup is served regardless of religious affiliationâ€”Jewish food is everywhere in Odesa.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Jewish kosher corners and traditional Odesa restaurants like Maman

hero_dishes.name: Rapa Whelk
hero_dishes.description: Black Sea snail baked with chopped garlic, fried onion, spices, and sour cream
hero_dishes.origin_story: Commonly caught by local fishermen in the Black Sea, this unique mollusk showcases Odesa's port city reliance on what the sea provides.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Local seafood restaurants and Privoz Market

signature_drinks.name: Kvass
signature_drinks.description: Non-alcoholic drink made from rye bread, dark, bubbly, and refreshing
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sold at Privoz Market and street vendors. Locals drink it cold during hot Black Sea summers for quick refreshment.

signature_drinks.name: Dry White Wine (Champagne-style)
signature_drinks.description: Local fruity, bubbly white wine similar to champagne, available at market tastings
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in small tasting glasses at Privoz Market wine stalls, paired with local cheese and sausages.
